review_blob: Really disappointed by this, but didnt actually have high expectations. Aroma is wet cardboard, or maybe its particle board. Cant make out any of the floral aspects. Was hoping for a bit more tang on the tongue, but that isnt there either. It has a hint of the orange peel mouth feel, but I had to hunt to find that. Not "big" at all.
beer_name: Monteiths Brewers Series Double Hopped IPA

review_blob: I drank this on a cool Autumn evening from a long stemmed glass, like I was told to. This is a classy drop, lovely fruity, orange peel in the nose and mouth. Its a really good one to throw around and squeeze into the roof of your mouth. The aftertaste could keep you happy for another 20 minutes. And quite the kick too.
Bought as Melchers Dutch Gold, mainly because it was only $4 and was looking for a bargain. It looked good in the glass until I tasted it. Did Rembrandt clean his brushes with this?

Pours and looks fine. Aroma is hard to put a finger on, but reminds me of something I cant quite recall, maybe it was a stronger-type beer.
This is quite nice in the mouth, a bit gingery, but quite refreshing. Bit short on presence and somewhat metallic. Overall OK, but needs to go in one direction or another, either more hops or more malt.
beer_name: Matilda Bay Fat Yak Pale Ale

review_blob:
This one pours a golden bronze colour with a good looking head. It has that wheat beer coriander smell with marmalade in there too. 
Doesnt smell like a hoppy IPA but more a Belgian with a hop-loaded minimi.
Nice and velvety in the mouth, and more marmalade or orange peel coming behind it.
A bit too thick and cloying to feel like an IPA, the aftertaste sticks with you for a long time, which is a great thing, you get more value. 
I went into this thinking I was buying into an IPA, but I got swindled into a delicious Belgian with hops. Bugger.

Got from the fill your own at Regional Wines & Spirits. Pours nice bronze colour but head disappears quickly. Hops smell resiny and strong, but you dont get that in the mouth. Not much carbonation. Nice and bitter, but not astringent, on top of the malt. Pretty classy wee drop.

bread, bubblegum, medium bitterness, lightly sour, paper napkin, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, golden, hazy, frothy then minimal head.
Those were the prompt words, not sure where to put this. It initially smells like a bog-standard lager but has a bit more depth and artesian well feel to it. Well-made beer, but not my favourite style.

There was a time, in my youth, when I thought this was awesome. Exported around the world because of its goodness.
I dont know what I was thinking. It now pours a thin head, which disappears. It used to look like straw,  it now looks like urine. 
What used to be a hoppy aroma is now just skunk. It used to be reasonably priced.  Dare I say it smells cheap? Sweetish taste, little bit biscuity, but has an underlying funk which makes it questionable. No recognisable aftertaste.
Once was inspiring, now brewed by an accountant and flogged by Madison Ave? Lets recall it.

Pours an attractive wood colour with ok head that didnt last overly long but it kept its bead. Lovely citrus aroma, grapefruit and pine which promises a delicious zingy beer. On the tongue it is bright and very bitter, the orange rind taste on the tongue is thoroughly pleasant. Not sure if I can taste any malt, thatll be my limited sense of taste, but the hops are not the only thing in this beer. However, they are the predominant theme. At 7% its nice and heady. Top drop/

Aroma greets you from 6ft away, syrupy, caramel? marmalade? Whatever it is, it is delicious. Quite a bitter mouthfeel, tart and abrupt. This smacks of a well-made beer and worth whatever it was I paid for it. 43 different hops and 65 malts? Are they taking the piss? There was no alcohol content on the label of the bottle I bought, which is illegal in this country, nonetheless, i would break the law to buy this again.

I like this beer. Big floral marmaladey, grapefruit nose and nice and tart in the mouth. Makes me think of a grassy field in the summer sun, on a hill somewhere. Probably overlooking a river and I dont have to go to work very soon. Feels good in your mouth to swish around, giving you more orange rind aftersmack. Good headiness at 5.8%. They should all be like this.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Poured this from the bottle, probably too warm. The head disappeared within a minute to leave a cola brown fizzy liquid. Good, promising nose which reminded me of aniseed/weak licorice. Medium body and a fizziness that quickly disappears, along with an abrupt finish. Cant taste the 8.2% alcohol at all. Best thing about this beer is the aroma, but overall I was disappointed and cant understand what the hype is all about. It cant all be down to the temperature.

Was looking forward to this. Pours with a nice thick, foamy head, but quite big bubbles. Nice piney, resiny hop aroma.  
It fills and expands in the mouth like concentrated marmalade with lots of fruits, malt and bitterness. Good balance of flavours but with its high alcohol its quite overpowering. I wish it was sessionable, so I could drink more.

Pours a black that reminds me of some sort of thick coca-cola. Thin but attractive tan head and smells of vegemite. Quite fizzy for a stout which makes it seem thin. Quite bitter but nice and dry finish. Vegemite still there in the mouth, if a bit metallic. When I first tried this 15 years ago it was brilliant, not sure it is the same beer now though.

I was attracted to the good looking man on the label.
Poured dark-coloured with a hint of auburn and a thick head which quickly dissipated to a thin crema.
The  aroma reminded me of caramel and bread. It felt thick on the tongue but was neither overly sweet nor bitter. Is this umami, a word I have never heard of? Probably not.
However, it left me sucking my tongue to try and find out more.
Overall a pretty solid beer but not striking out in any direction, which might be its strength. 
It tastes like a good session beer,but its 7.6%. Wow. I reckon this could grow on me.

Not sure why this is exported around the world, its not helping anybody. An unremarkable drop, light sweetness and body with a thinness about it. Gassy enough to repeat on you quickly and not an enjoyable belch either.

Bought this in a bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits, not sure why, probably liked the name despite being wary of NZ attempts at strong beers.
It poured jet black with a surprisingly foamy rich looking tan head, which didnt disappear. The aroma is fantastic; coffee and a slight hint of metal which sings promise.
In the mouth it is slightly oily and cloying, and the coffee continues, along with lots of other rich flavours, licorice and chocolate. It doesnt feel too alcoholic, but you know its there when you breathe out.
It has a medium sweetness but doesnt stick around in the mouth. Nice balance is what I thought.
Brilliant drop, knock a bollock off to try one.
